newsitem.title: NEPAL: General strike call brings Nepal capital to halt.
newsitem.headline: General strike call brings Nepal capital to halt.

text.p: A general strike led by Nepal's opposition communists brought much of Kathmandu to a halt on Wednesday in the first major political protest against the ruling centre-right coalition.

Public transport, educational institutions and businesses closed in response to the strike call by the communist-led National Mass Movement Coordination Committee (NMMCC) but some industries stayed open, witnesses said.
The protesters say Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba's Nepali Congress-led coalition is responsible for corruption, high inflation and unemployment in the landlocked Himalayan kingom.
They criticise Deuba's government for its signing in February of a treaty with India to share the waters of the Mahakali river, which they say is not fair to Nepal.
The treaty is now before the Nepali parliament for ratification.

The strikers have also accused the government of harassing innocent people and political rivals in western Nepal under the guise of a crackdown on Maoist rebels in an insurgency which has claimed more than 40 lives in the past six months.
Witnesses said most shops in the main business area of Kathmandu were closed and only a few taxi cabs and three-wheeled auto-rickshaws were running.

The strike, which came a day after the end of a three-month closure by textile mills opposing a rise in sales tax, was the first major showdown with the opposition since the government came to power last September.
The centre-right coalition assumed power after dislodging in a confidence vote a communist minority government which had ruled for nine months.
Nepal launched a multi-party democracy under a constitutional monarchy headed by King Birendra in 1990 after bloody pro-democracy demonstrations.
